I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic  approach  for  the  Boosting  Productivity  through  Human  Capital  Development 
Program, and (ii) a proposed policy-based loan to the Republic of Indonesia for subprogram 1 of 
the Boosting Productivity through Human Capital Development Program. 
 
2.  Human capital refers to the set of skills, knowledge, competencies, and other attributes 
embodied in people; and plays a key role in a country’s long-run growth prospects. Its role is 
especially relevant given the economic disruption resulting from the coronavirus disease (COVID-
19) pandemic. The program focuses on human capital development to improve labor productivity 
that will be especially important for COVID-19 recovery. It supports reforms in education, skills 
development, health, and social assistance, within an overarching Sustainable Development Goal 
(SDG) framework and aims to achieve the key targets highlighted in Box 1. The program adopts 
a programmatic approach that combines policy-based loans with technical assistance (TA) and 
knowledge support. This approach was selected as it enables the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to partner with the Government of Indonesia to pursue high-impact reforms sequentially over three 
subprograms.  Subprogram  1  establishes the foundation  of  the program through regulatory 
reforms and pilot initiatives; subprogram 2 will focus on the implementation and expansion of 
these reforms; and subprogram 3 will institutionalize these reforms, so that they form a permanent 
part of the national framework.

II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Macroeconomic context. With the unprecedented impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, 
Indonesia’s economy contracted by 2.1% in 2020—for the first time since the Asian financial 
crisis.1 Per capita gross national income declined to $3,870 and Indonesia was reclassified as a 
lower middle-income country in 2021.2 The government expects real gross domestic product 
(GDP) growth of 3.7%–4.5% in 2021, down from its earlier outlook of 5.0%–5.3% primarily

because of the mobility restrictions put in place to stem the spike in COVID-19 infections. The 
government’s macroeconomic framework remains satisfactory. Given the stimulus packages to 
address the impacts of the pandemic, the 2021 budget targets a deficit of 5.7% of GDP.3 A return 
to pre-pandemic levels of fiscal prudence is planned by 2023. With inflation remaining subdued, 
the central bank has kept the policy rate at 3.5%, its lowest level since 2016. Public debt remains 
moderate at about 37.0% of GDP as of end-2020 and is projected to stabilize at about 43.0% over 
the medium term.4 The nonperforming loan ratio has inched up, while the capital adequacy ratio 
remains comfortably above the regulatory minimum.5 Notwithstanding, structural reforms will be 
important to stimulate economic recovery and achieve long-term national development goals. 
 
4.  Indonesia aspires to become a high-income country by 2045. Indonesia’s economic 
growth rate has flattened at an average of 5.0% since peaking at 9.5% in 1995–1996, just before 
the Asian Financial Crisis in 1997. This growth rate is high by global standards, but considerably 
lower compared with its regional peers and to the years preceding the crisis.6 For Indonesia to 
achieve high-income status by 2045, a growth rate of about 7.0% will be necessary, which will 
require an increase in labor productivity from its current low levels (Figure 1, Panel A). During 
1980–2019, labor productivity growth in the People’s Republic of China and Viet Nam was 
considerably higher. Examining Indonesia’s labor productivity and its determinants reveals that 
human capital in Indonesia plays a smaller role in driving productivity growth (Figure 1, Panel B). 
This is because of the low level of human capital, in terms of quantity as well as quality.

6.  Effect of COVID-19 on social indicators and human capital development. First, the 
poverty rate increased to 10.2% in 2020 from 9.2% in 2019, reversing the gains of prior years.9 
Second, job losses have been unprecedented, with the unemployment rate spiking to 7.1% in 
2020 from 5.3% in 2019. Women are bearing the brunt of the impact as they make up a larger 
proportion of the workforce in some of the most impacted industries such as tourism, and 
wholesale and retail.10 Third, learning outcomes have worsened because of COVID-19-related 
school closures. Three out of four households in Indonesia were concerned about learning loss 
for their children because of extended school closures.11 Missed schooling at an early age could 
have a lasting impact on incomes and livelihoods. Half a year of learning loss could lead to $224.4 
billion in lifetime income losses across 68 million students.12 Fourth, non-COVID-19 public health 
outcomes have also deteriorated, as evidenced by a reduction in immunization rates and access 
to non-COVID-19 health care. Recent evidence shows that 1 in 10 households reported missing 
immunization for children under the age of 5 (footnote 11). 
 
7.  Indonesia must address its human capital deficit to meet its targeted growth rate.13

existing technologies and products, they still need a workforce with relevant skills and knowledge. 
Yet,  employers  in  Indonesia  report  a  scarcity  of  workers  with  job-ready  skills,  which  is

a more knowledge-driven economy, demand for high-skilled workers will further grow. 
 
8.  Development constraints. The government has recognized these challenges and has 
identified three key binding constraints to human capital development: (i) incomplete fiscal policies 
and monitoring tools, impeding the implementation of the SDGs; (ii) low quality and relevance of 
education  and  training,  leaving  young  people  underprepared  for  the  labor  market;  and  
(iii) inadequate social protection and health policies to achieve human capital development. 
 
9.  Incomplete fiscal policies and monitoring tools impede the implementation of the 
SDGs. Three key issues contribute to this binding constraint. First, the alignment between SDG 
priorities and the fiscal framework is insufficient at the subnational government level, especially 
for health expenditures. This constraint leads to discrepancies in SDG implementation at the local 
level. For example, the percentage of women who gave birth in a health facility in Jakarta exceeds 
99% compared to about 40% in Maluku. Second, the SDG target on universal health coverage 
through the national health insurance system is at risk as the insurance scheme is in a precarious 
fiscal position and is unable to address the health inequities across Indonesia. The health 
insurance premium rates need to be adjusted based on factors such as the payment of variable 
benefits across different classes, the ability of beneficiaries to pay the contributions, and the fiscal 
cost to the government. Third, fiscal transfers for health are inadequate and do not include targets 
for health expenses, leading to underspending in health programs such as on stunting prevention. 
 
10.  The  low  quality  and  relevance  of  education  and  training  leave  young  people 
underprepared for the labor market. Four key issues contribute to this binding constraint. First, 
the local public employment service centers cannot meet the demands of the rising numbers of 
better educated but unemployed youth. Indonesia’s percentage of youth not in employment, 
education, and training (NEET) has been declining but was still elevated at 20.5% (the rate is 
higher, at 26.2%, for females) in 2019; higher than in the Philippines (18.8%), Thailand (14.9%), 
and Viet Nam (14.4%).15 Second, training provided by technical and vocational education and 
training (TVET) institutions does not prepare students for employment because coordination 
among TVET policies, TVET providers, and industry associations is weak. Studies have shown 
that graduates of TVET programs have difficulty finding employment because of poor quality 
programs and the mismatch between the skills provided and labor market demand.16 Third, 
learning deficits start early for Indonesian youth, with poor learning outcomes reinforced every 
year because of, among others, a lack of innovative thinking on the delivery of education. 
Evidence shows that new and emerging education technologies have not been used optimally 
(i.e., targeted at improving teaching and learning) to make a difference in learning outcomes, and 
teachers  lack  the  capacity  to  use  education  technologies  to  improve  children’s  learning 
experience.17 Fourth, quality varies widely across higher education institutions and a number of 
them  lack  innovative  approaches  in  using  digital  technology  to  improve  the  quality  and 
competitiveness of education and research. The job placement of higher education graduates in

11.  Social protection and health policies are not sufficient to achieve human capital 
development objectives. Four key issues contribute to this binding constraint. First, even with 
increased social protection following the COVID-19 outbreak, the coverage and adequacy of 
social protection remain lower than the regional average. For instance, an unemployment benefit 
framework is lacking. In the absence of such a framework, households that are otherwise above 
the poverty line and in employment may suddenly face the risk of slipping into poverty because 
of job losses. More households headed by women (56.7%) said they did not have savings to help 
cushion the impact of the COVID-19 crisis compared with those headed by men (50.6%) (footnote 
11). Second, beneficiary databases across different social protection programs are not aligned. 
This has led to inclusion and exclusion errors in targeting and has undermined social protection 
coverage and effectiveness. Third, policy coherence and effective interagency coordination to 
address stunting are lacking. Stunting is a complex issue which requires several layers of 
interventions to make an impact, recent evaluation of development partners’ supported programs 
have not been encouraging. According to the most recent data, 27.7% of children under the age 
of 5 exhibited signs of stunting, above the 25.7% average for Southeast Asia.18 Stunting is often 
caused by malnutrition and poor health (sanitation) in early childhood and can prevent children 
from reaching their full physical and mental potential later in life, causing large long-term economic 
costs. The costs of stunting are inter-generational, as mothers who experienced stunting during 
their childhoods are more likely to have children who suffer from stunting. Fourth, given the clear 
synergies between health, nutrition policies, and educational outcomes among children and 
young adults, the government’s health sector strategy needs to be better aligned with human 
capital development objectives. 
 
12.  Strategic alignment. The program is aligned with the government’s Vision of Indonesia 
2045 and National Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJMN), 2020–2024, which focus on 
human resources development.19 It is also aligned with the first strategic pathway, on improving 
well-being (covering health, social protection, education, and workforce skills), of ADB’s country 
partnership strategy for Indonesia, 2020–2024; and is included in the country operations business 
plan for Indonesia, 2021–2023.20 The program contributes to ADB Strategy 2030 operational 
priorities on addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; accelerating progress in 
gender equality; tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental sustainability; and strengthening governance and institutional capacity.21

14.  Programmatic  approach  and  budget  support.  The  program,  consisting  of  three 
subprograms,  aims  to  enhance  labor  productivity  through  human  capital  development.22 It 
focuses on three critical reform areas: (i) strengthened policies to finance and monitor  the 
implementation of the SDGs; (ii) improved educational attainment and skills development; and  
(iii) enhanced social protection and public health systems. While each of these areas is highly 
critical and may have benefitted from a separate dedicated program on its own, this program 
cluster adopts the approach of providing a high-level overarching framework which will be 
supplemented by a series of investment projects. All 12 prior actions for subprogram 1 have been 
completed. Channels through which the program will enhance human capital in Indonesia include 
more inclusive and sustainable health insurance, improved quality of education and TVET, more 
inclusive and equitable social protection, and enhanced quality of health care (Figure 3). Some of 
the policy actions will have a direct and immediate impact on human capital, while others will have 
an indirect impact leading to gradual improvement over a longer period. The program has made 
notable achievements under subprogram 1 (Box 2).

Box 2: Notable Achievements Under Subprogram 1 
 
•  Fourteen Sustainable Development Goal centers, in partnership with local universities, were added 
across Indonesia, which will play an important role in localizing the implementation of the 
Sustainable Development Goals and in supporting subnational governments. 
 
•  The preemployment card program was introduced, covering more than 5.0 million beneficiaries in 
2020 and 2.7 million beneficiaries in 2021 (of whom 47% are women) across 34 provinces.  
 
•  The government introduced the Jaminan Kehilangan Pekerjaan (JKP) unemployment benefit

12.4 million workers (9.1% of the labor force). 
 
•  To prepare teachers for student-centered teaching and learning practices, the government 
implemented a digital marketplace for in-service training aimed at teachers across the country. As 
of the second quarter of 2021, 8,225 teachers have gone through the program, including 64%

15.  Reform area 1: Strengthened policies to finance and monitor the implementation of 
the Sustainable Development Goals. This reform area focuses on the overall monitoring and 
implementation of SDGs including at the local level, as well as financing (budget allocation and 
fiscal transfers) of health programs to meet SDG targets such as universal health coverage. The 
reform area supports SDG 1 (no poverty), SDG 3 (good health), and SDG 5 (gender equality). 
Three key reforms were achieved in subprogram 1. First, the government increased the number 
of SDG centers to 23, from nine before the program. These SDG centers are set up in partnership 
with local universities and will play an important role in localizing SDGs to help subnational 
governments plan and monitor the implementation of local SDG programs. These centers will 
also strengthen participation and ownership at the local level for overall SDG implementation. 
Second, related to SDG 3, and to make the national health insurance more sustainable and yet 
affordable for lower-income groups, the government through issuance of a Presidential regulation, 
increased the monthly premium for first-class service from $5.6 to $10.5 per person, and for 
second-class service from $3.6 to $7.0 per person. The premium for third-class service was also 
increased from $1.8 to $2.9 per person, but this was partially subsidized.23 Total subsidies for the 
poor and vulnerable groups were increased from approximately $1.9 billion in 2019 to $3.4 billion 
in 2020. The regulation also mandated a review of the health benefits included in the insurance. 
Third, to increase health expenditures and outcomes at the subnational level, the government 
earmarked 8% of the general allocation fund and 30% of the regional incentive fund transferred 
to  local  governments  for  health  expenditures.24 In  addition,  acknowledging  the  connection 
between women’s welfare and stunting reduction, the government also issued regulations that 
require subnational governments to prioritize spending on direct stunting reduction and women’s 
participation in economic activities at the village level. 
 
16.  The government will build on these reforms in subprograms 2 and 3 to achieve the 
outcome  indicators  related  to  improvement  in  the  SDG  index  score.  To  support  SDG 
implementation by subnational governments, the government will expand the SDG centers to all 
34 provinces by 2025. Additional fiscal and capacity support will be provided to provinces with 
lagging performance. The government will also streamline benefits across the treatment classes

17.  Reform area 2: Improved educational attainment and skills development. This reform 
area focuses on educational and skills development outcomes and supports SDG 4 (quality 
education), SDG 5 (gender equality), and SDG 8 (decent work). Five key reforms were achieved 
in subprogram 1. First, to address unemployment, including unemployment resulting from the 
COVID-19 pandemic, the government launched the preemployment card (Kartu Pra Kerja) 
program to provide subsidized training and job search allowance for job seekers. The program 
covered more than 5 million beneficiaries in 2020 and an additional 2.7 million beneficiaries in 
2021, across all 34 provinces. Implementation in the first half of 2021 also saw an increase in 
women’s participation to from 45% in 2020 to 50% of beneficiaries. Second, to complement the 
implementation of the preemployment card and to improve labor market prospects for youth, the 
government implemented JobStart Indonesia in Bandung Barat and Makassar, which included 
45% female job seekers and provided gender-responsive skills training modules.25

C.  Expected Outcome of the Reforms 
 
25.  The overarching development objectives that the program is aligned with is improvement 
of human quality in Indonesia, based on the RPJMN, and human development and mastery of 
science and technology, based on Vision 2045 (footnote 19). The outcome of the reform is 
improved human capital development. This is also consistent with the government’s SDG road 
map. The effect of the reforms will be demonstrated by the performance targets in the policy 
design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
26.  Results. The program contributes to the government’s medium-term development targets. 
Overall, the program is expected to improve Indonesia’s HCI from 54% in 2020 to 59% in 2026. 
This rate of improvement will be faster than Indonesia’s experience since 2010 when Indonesia’s 
HCI was at 50%. Customized outcome indicators were also included to measure the success of 
each reform area. In reform area 1, the coverage of the national health insurance is expected to 
increase from 223 million people in 2020 to 240 million people in 2026, thereby bringing Indonesia 
closer to attainment of universal healthcare. In reform area 2, the gap in the NEET rate between 
men and women is expected to narrow from 11.12 percentage points in 2020 to 7.50 percentage 
points in 2026. The percentage of higher education graduates who find work within 1 year of 
graduation is targeted to increase from 64.7% in 2020 to 66.7% in 2026. Outcome indicators for 
reform area 3 include increased social safety net coverage of the poorest quintile from 66% in 
2020 to 75% in 2026 and a reduction in stunting among children under age 5 years old from 27.7% 
in 2019 to 14.0% in 2026. An assessment of the program’s impact reveals that benefits will accrue 
to poorer and vulnerable Indonesians in the form of higher wages and better employment 
outcomes than would otherwise have been observed.35 
 
27.  Benefits to the private sector. The program’s overarching objective of improving labor 
productivity is closely linked to private sector development. This is especially demonstrated 
through policy actions in reform areas 2 and 3. Skilled and healthy labor is critical for private 
enterprises to invest and prosper in Indonesia. Reforms such as the unemployment benefit 
program are equally important as they allow the government to reduce severance pay and thereby 
make the labor market more flexible. In addition, the private sector is an integral part of several 
reform initiatives. JobStart includes private sector consultations, so that the life skills and technical 
training are demand based. Private sector representatives are included in the steering committee 
to prepare for the establishment of the national TVET committee. To ensure that the pace of 
reforms is consistent and that private sector beneficiaries feel the intended effects, a monitoring 
and feedback mechanism will include private sector representatives (para. 31).

D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
 
28.  The government projects its financing needs to be $99.1 billion in 2021, which will be met 
through domestic ($70.8 billion–$83.0 billion) and foreign ($19.0 billion–$23.5 billion) sources. 
The government’s fiscal stance remains flexible to respond to public health needs arising from 
the COVID-19 pandemic. The proposed programmatic approach comprising three subprograms 
is estimated to cost $1.5 billion. Subprogram 1 of $500 million is estimated to represent 0.5% of 
the government’s financing needs in 2021. The size of the loan is based on the country’s current 
financing needs and the impact of the reforms. Over the medium term, the financing gap for SDG 
implementation up to 2030 is estimated to exceed $1 trillion. The government’s budget allocation 
in 2021 to implement the reforms in subprogram 1 exceeds $20 billion. This includes significant 
allocations for SDG implementation (about $5.0 billion), stunting (about $3.1 billion), and national 
health insurance ($3.4 billion). 
 
29.  The government has requested a regular loan of $500 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance subprogram 1. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace 
period of 3 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such 
other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on the straight-line 
repayment method, the average maturity is 9.25 years, and no maturity premium is payable to 
ADB. German development cooperation through KfW is expected to provide parallel cofinancing 
of 400 million Euros for subprogram 1. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
30.  The CMEA will be the executing agency. BAPPENAS; the Ministry of Finance; the Ministry 
of Education, Culture, Research and Technology; the Ministry of Social Affairs; the Ministry of 
Manpower; and the Ministry of Health will be the implementing agencies. The implementation 
period will be from August 2019 to August 2021 for subprogram 1, from September 2021 to 
July 2023 for subprogram 2, and from August 2023 to July 2025 for subprogram 3.  The proceeds 
of the policy-based loan will be withdrawn following ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, 
as amended from time to time).36 The likely disbursement date will be the first quarter of 2022. 
 
31.  Program monitoring mechanisms. The CMEA, as the executing agency, will hold 
monitoring meetings twice a year with the implementing agencies, ADB, and the program’s 
cofinancing partner(s). Chaired by the deputy minister, the meetings will monitor progress and 
coordinate knowledge work and TA. The findings from the meetings will guide the implementation 
of the program as well the government’s broader reform measures.

in  a  decade,  from  5.3%  in  2019.  The  youth  unemployment  rate  also  increased  to  
20.5% in 2020 from 18.6% in 2019. The program’s reform measures will contribute to poverty 
reduction and better labor market outcomes in Indonesia.  The program will support better 
coverage  and  targeting  of  social  protection  programs  and  will  provide  income  support  to

The program focuses on human capital development to improve labor productivity that will be especially important for COVID-19 recovery. It supports reforms in education, skills development, health, and social assistance, within an overarching Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) framework.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated July 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54461-001 in Indonesia.
